data: They are providing the protocols for the web standards - Founder : Tim Berners-Lee

ans.data: DOM stands for Document Object Model
It is a programming interface use to manipulate elements, styles, events and etc.,
HTML DOM converts html elements, properties and their methods into object.
It used to add, get, change or delete the HTML elements.

qus: What are the Scopes are available in Javascript ?

ans.data: Hoisting is the default behavior of moving all the declarations at the top of the scope before code execution.
JavaScript only hoists declarations, not initializations.

A factory function can be defined as a function that creates an object and returns it.
 function name will be in camelCase.
Constructor enables to provide custom initialization that must be done before any other methods can be called on an instantiated object .
Constructor function name should be in Pascal Case .
this keyword can be used inside of the constructor function.
It will automatically return the result, no need to write return keyword.

Syntax : 
 function Person() { // Pascal Case 
 this.name = 'vijay',// this refers to create 
 this.age  = 29 
 } 

 var person   = new Person();  // new keyword refers to create new object 
 console.log(person.age);

ans.data: Coercion refers to the process of automatic or implicit conversion of values from one data type to another.

data: === - Value and Type Comparison Equal To

ans.data: 42 == '42' // true : compares the value (Equality Operator)
42 === '42' // false : compares the value and data type (Strict Equality Operator)
Template Literal Uses Backtick ``

The nullish coalescing (??) operator is a logical operator that returns its right-hand side operand when its left-hand side operand is null or undefined, and otherwise returns its left-hand side operand.
Closure allows inner functions to access the outer scope of a function

qus: What are the array methods in Javascript ?

data: Array length - Returns array length value // array.length
Array toString() - Converts an array to a string of (comma separated) array values. //array.toString();
Array at() - Returns at position of array values. // array.at(2) || array[2]
Array join() - This method also joins all array elements into a string. // array.join(',');
Array pop() - This method removes the last element from an array. // array.pop();
Array push() - This method adds a new element to an array (at the end). // array.push('text');
Array shift() - This method removes the first array element and "shifts" all other elements to a lower index. // array.shift();
Array unshift() - This method adds a new element to an array (at the beginning), and "unshifts" older elements. // array.unshift('text');
Array delete() - Using delete() leaves undefined holes in the array. // delete array[2];
Array concat() - This method creates a new array by merging (concatenating) existing arrays. // array1.concat(array2);
Array copyWithin() - This method copies array elements to another position in an array. // array1.copyWithin(2, 0);
Array splice() - This method can be used to add new items to an array. // array1.splice(2, 0, "new item", "new item");
Array slice() - This method slices out a piece of an array into a new array. // array1.slice(2);

ans.data: The Object.create() static method creates a new object, using an existing object as the prototype of the newly created object.

qus: What is dot operator(.) used for ?

ans.data: dot operator used to access the properties inside of an object.

Example 
 let person = { 
 firstName : "john", 
 lastName  : "doe", 
 age:25 
 } 
 console.log(person.firstName) // access the object value using dot operator
Array notation is the method to access the properties using square bracket.

Example 
 let person = { 
 firstName : "john", 
 lastName  : "doe", 
 age:25 
 } 
 console.log(person['firstName']) // access the object value using dot operator

qus: What is in operator (in) used for ?

ans.data: The in operator returns true if the specified property is in the specified object or its prototype chain.

Example 
 let person = { 
 firstName : "john", 
 lastName  : "doe", 
 age:25 
 } 
 console.log('firstName' in person) // true

qus: How to delete a property from an Object ?

ans.data: The "delete" keyword used to delete object property.

Example 
 let person = { 
 firstName : "john", 
 lastName  : "doe", 
 age:25 
 } 
 console.log(delete person.age) // delete the age property from object

qus: Is Javascript single threaded or multi threaded ?

ans.data: Javascript is a single threaded. As it has single call stack.
Browser API's are Asynchronus.
They are added in the queue.
Then It goes to call stack.
Queue to call stack moving is called as execution.

qus: Is Javascript Static Language or Dynamic Language ?

ans.data: Javascript is a dynamic language as we can change the values and types.
Preincrement

data: ++a returns the value of a after it has been incremented.

ans.data: Postincrement

data: a++ returns the value of a before incrementing.

ans.data: The querySelector() method returns the first child element that matches a specified CSS selector(s) of an element
"Note": The querySelector() method only returns the first element that matches the specified selectors. To return all the matches, use the querySelectorAll() method instead.
JavaScript Classes are templates for JavaScript Objects.
The example above creates a class named "Car".
The class has two initial properties: "name" and "year".
A JavaScript class is not an object. It is a template for JavaScript objects

qus: Differences of var let and Const ?

ans.data: In JavaScript, users can declare a variable using three keywords that are var, let, and const. The behavior and the scope of a variable are also based on the keyword used to define it.
var

data: In JavaScript. It has the Global scoped or function scoped
It means variables defined outside the function can be accessed globally

ans.data: let

data: The let keyword is an improved version of the var keyword.
These variables has the block scope.
It can’t be accessible outside the particular code block ({block}).

ans.data: const

data: The user cannot update it and have to assign it with a value at the time of declaration.
These variables also have the block scope.
It is mainly used to create constant variables whose values can not be changed once they are initialized with a value.

ans.data: Abstraction in computer programming is a way to reduce complexity and allow efficient design and implementation in complex software systems.
Advantages

data: Helps the user to avoid writing low-level code.
Avoids code duplication and increases reusability.
Can change the internal implementation of a class independently without affecting the user.
Helps to increase the security of an application or program as only important details are provided to the user.

ans.data: The try...catch statement is comprised of a try block and either a catch block, a finally block, or both. The code in the try block is executed first, and if it throws an exception, the code in the catch block will be executed. The code in the finally block will always be executed before control flow exits the entire construct.
Anonymous functions are functions that do not have a name. They can be assigned to variables or passed as arguments to higher order functions.
